definition: to put one's hands on one's hips/also written 插腰[cha1 yao1]

sentences.english: She stood three feet high and her hands rested on her hips.
He stood there with his hands on his hips.
The crafts tilted his head hand akimbo Zhang splayleg standing.
sentences.chinese: 工艺品歪着头，一手叉腰，站在。

sentences.english: I'm just standing here with my thumb up my butt.
sentences.chinese: 我只是站在这里，两手叉腰，什么都没干。

sentences.english: Three weeks later he came into my office with his hands on his hips.
sentences.chinese: 三个星期后，他来到我的办公室，两手叉腰。
他两手叉腰，站在铺子前。

sentences.english: Children standing akimbo by the fence.
Their Captain sat on his horse, arms akimbo, surveying the scene.
sentences.chinese: 史松双手叉腰，骑在马上掠阵。

sentences.english: The mistress stood with arms akimbo while she talked to her new servant.
sentences.chinese: 女主人双手叉腰站著对他的新仆人说话。

definition: to put one's hands on one's hips
to open one's eyes wide/to stare/to glare (at sb)/to scowl
lit. furrowed brows and blazing eyes/to dart looks of hate at sb (idiom)
to pout (to express anger or displeasure)
to sway one's hips/to twist one's waist
to protrude/to stick out/to pout (also written 噘)/to embarrass (people)
hand gesture in traditional dances (joined thumb and middle finger, the rest extended)
